'''The Lady of the Sun'''<ref name=spirits>{{SD|3vi5}}, p. 426</ref> was a character that exists within the folk-tales of the [[Shire-hobbits]],<ref name=tlotr>{{FR|I9}}</ref> the [[Númenóreans]],<ref name=spirits/> and [[Gondorians]].<ref name=preface/>

== History ==
The Lady of the Sun<ref name=spirits/> in [[Middle-earth]] folklore may have her origins in the legend of [[Arien]] the [[Maiar|Maia]].

The [[Númenóreans]] believed that The Lady of the Sun, like ''[[Nîlû]]'', was a [[spirits|guardian spirit]] and named her '''''Ûrî'''''.<ref name=spirits/>

According to [[Middle-earth]] folklore, The Lady of the Sun<ref name=spirits/> had fiery eyes. After the [[Man in the Moon]]'s misadventure on [[Arda]] in [[Bilbo Baggins]]'s<ref name=preface/> song ''[[The Man in the Moon Stayed Up Too Late]]'', The Lady of the Sun<ref name=spirits/> appeared surprised that no one was awake despite it being daytime.<ref name=poem5/>

In ''[[The Man in the Moon Came Down Too Soon]]'', a song derived from [[Gondorians|Gondorian]] lore,<ref name=preface/> it is said that the Man in the Moon "longed for '''Fire'''" in his heart, possibly implying that he longed for The Lady of the Sun<ref name=spirits/>.<ref name=poem6>{{AB|6}}</ref>

== Etymology ==
The [[Adûnaic]] name ''Ûrî'' is given as the female personification of ''ûre'' ("the Sun"), referring to its guardian spirit.<ref name=spirits/>
